8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:03): the latest opera beta didn't have new-style postMessage support, did it?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (02:26): I was reading about externality taxing in the CO2 context on the plane
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (02:27): the economics of it seem applicable to inaccessible Web pages
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (02:27): except tracking tax on those would be more difficult
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:29): "on the plane"?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (02:29): 8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33: while flying back from Dublin
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:29): was binding "the CO2 context on the plane" as one unit
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (02:30): notes that Tim Harford writes about "moral posturing" in the absence of externality taxing
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (02:31): threatening people with lawsuits is a kind of an externality tax
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (02:31): but an uncertain one that applies only to big companies
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:31): a hideously less efficient one, to be sure
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:31): courts and lawsuits epitomize deadweight loss
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (02:32): I'm not a fan of lawsuit threatening as part of the accessibility advocate argument set
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:32): I think it would be hard to justify a large tax on inaccessible web pages on a Pigovian basis
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:33): in fact pure economic analysis might find the cost of making web pages accesible exceeds the likely economic benefit
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:33): I'm also not sure lack of accessibility can be modeled as a negative externality
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:33): rather, it is failure to provide a positive good to some people
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:34): pollution is a negative externality
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:34): giving free candy to some people but not others isn't

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (02:34): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: I agree that presence should be considered a positive thing, but you can't start subsidising anyone with an inane Web site for making it accessible
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:36): current approaches to accesibility in law involve neither subsidy nor tax
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:36): rather they rely on legal notions of public accomodation, and impose regulations on anything considered such
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:37): is reasonably happy with how that's fallen out so far
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:37): well, it does create unintended consequences
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (02:37): I thought in the U.S. they relied on punitive damages acting as a probabilistic externality tex
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:37): I'm not sure what actually motivates orgs at the end of the day
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:38): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: the same could be said of most regulations
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:38): government business is at least part of it
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:38): however the risk of damages does create unintended consequences
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:38): for instance, since the ADA passed, unemployment among the disabled is up
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (02:38): yeah, 508-based government sales are the carrot
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (02:39): on the other hand, I seem to recall it was this channel that mentioned <http://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/20/magazine/20wwln-freak-t.html?_r=1&oref=slogin> once
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:39): government business seems like a better motivator
